Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Whole Slide Imaging and Microscopy for Primary Diagnosis in Surgical Pathology

Trial_Design.evidence: The unit of randomisation was the individual case.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded surgical pathology cases, excluding frozen sections and consultation cases. The study was conducted at two academic centers and two commercial laboratories.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention was WSI, with microscopy as the comparator.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to demonstrate that whole slide imaging (WSI) is noninferior to microscopy for primary diagnosis in surgical pathology.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the major discordance rate between each modality and the reference standard diagnosis, measured over a 14-month period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using an Electronic Data Capture system, with allocation concealment ensured by deidentification.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to the reference standard.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1992 cases were analysed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 1992 cases were analysed, resulting in 15,925 reads.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The major discordance rate was 4.9% for WSI and 4.6% for microscopy. The difference in major discordance rates was 0.4% (95% CI, −0.30% to 1.01%), indicating noninferiority of WSI.
